title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett officials canceled Fiesta Del Rio due to recent ICE raids, affecting community safety during Hispanic Heritage Month.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria cited fear and uncertainty among residents as the reason for canceling the Sept. 20 event.
Fiesta Del Rio was to include live music and local vendors, celebrating Hispanic culture at Rivergreen Park.

title: Josh Kraft ends mayoral campaign after coming in second by nearly 50 points in Tuesday’s preliminary
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Josh Kraft ends his Boston mayoral campaign after losing the preliminary election to incumbent Mayor Michelle Wu by nearly 50 points.
Kraft, who never held public office, will donate $3 million to address a crisis near Massachusetts Ave and Melnea Cass Blvd.
Kraft's campaign focused on housing issues and raised $6.8 million, mostly self-funded, outpacing Wu's $1.8 million.

title: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye: ‘He’s the right guy’ for Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh McDaniels defends quarterback Drake Maye despite Week 1 struggles against the Raiders.
Drake Maye completed 14 of 20 throws for 150 yards and a touchdown but threw a costly interception.
Patriots may emphasize the run game with backs TreVeyon Henderson and Rhamondre Stevenson to aid Maye.

title: Authorities in a Connecticut town want to speak with whoever is painting the squirrels
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: East Hartford Animal Control reports squirrels in a Connecticut town were painted red and blue near Naubuc Avenue and High Street.
The painted squirrels appear unharmed, and authorities are working with a wildlife rehabilitator to provide appropriate aid.
Animal Control is seeking information about the incident and urges tips to be left at 860-291-7572.

title: 2 Mass. teachers reportedly on leave for reactions to Charlie Kirk’s death
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Two Massachusetts teachers are on administrative leave for social media reactions to the death of Charlie Kirk.
Wachusett and Framingham school districts confirmed investigations into teachers' comments regarding Kirk's shooting.
Holden Police ensured safety at WRHS; no credible threats reported despite social media responses causing concern.

title: A top return from Bruins’ roster teardown, prospect Fraser Minten is looking to stick in NHL
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Fraser Minten, acquired from Toronto by the Bruins, aims to secure a roster spot for the 2025-26 NHL season.
The Bruins' roster overhaul included trading veterans and acquiring prospects like Minten and draft picks for future team building.
Minten's versatility and maturity are highlighted as he prepares to lead in the 2025 Prospects Challenge in Buffalo.

title: Police issue all clear after UMass Boston reports ‘public safety threat’
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: UMass Boston issued an all-clear after a reported threat near the Residence Hall East Building on September 11, 2025.
Police confirmed no ongoing threat and no evidence of shots fired or firearms on the UMass Boston campus.
All evening classes and activities were canceled; students were advised to stay indoors during the incident.

title: ‘I would join a boycott’: Why readers oppose Market Basket’s firing of Artie T.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Market Basket's board fired CEO Arthur T. Demoulas after months of tension, citing refusal to share information.
Over 86% of Boston.com poll respondents oppose Demoulas's firing; 61% plan to boycott the grocery chain.
Conflict between Demoulas and his sisters, who own 60% of the company, is a longstanding family issue.

title: Boston City Council shows mixed support for rent control ballot question
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston City Council debated a resolution supporting a 2026 rent control ballot, but the discussion faced objections.
To place rent control on the Massachusetts ballot, advocates must gather 75,000 signatures after Attorney General approval.
Opponents in the real estate industry argue rent control could stall new housing construction and raise rental costs.

title: Haim praises Brick Street Bagels: ‘Bomb bagels’
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Haim praised Brick Street Bagels for having 'amazing' and 'bomb' bagels during a recent radio interview.
Brick Street Bagels, founded in 2022 by Jordan Renouf, is set to open a permanent location in South Boston this year.
The bakery is known for fresh, crunchy bagels and regularly runs pop-ups around South Boston and Cambridge.
